reasoning: The critique targets the role of “Common-sense utopia” as an illustrative/default-case meant to show that even very attractive-looking futures can be far from near-best due to non-obvious moral fragilities. If that vignette is illegitimately “too steered” (because enforcing a robust no-harm constraint and stable bargaining institutions arguably presupposes strong governance/alignment capacity), then the illustrative force of §2.3 weakens and the ‘fragility under default conditions’ claim is less supported. However, this is not the whole argument for “no easy eutopia”: much of the essay’s case also comes from the multiplicative-fragility framing and especially the later, more systematic discussion of fussy vs easygoing value functions. So centrality is moderate, not maximal. Strength is moderate: it plausibly exposes a hidden assumption mismatch between ‘no serious coordinated optimisation pressure’ and a world with globally reliable harm-accounting, but it doesn’t show that such capacity would in fact resolve most listed fragilities (e.g., population ethics, scale choices, value disagreements, bad-minimisation under separate aggregation, etc. can persist despite good governance). Correctness is high because the tension it points to is real, though it somewhat overclaims by suggesting robust no-harm enforcement would “plausibly correct several” of the hard moral-uncertainty items (it might reduce some failure modes without eliminating value-loss). The critique is clear, focused on a single issue, and contains little dead weight. Overall impact is limited because even granting it, the position can reply by (i) treating Common-sense utopia as a deliberately optimistic governance baseline, or (ii) noting that many fragilities concern value disagreement and deep normative facts not fixed by competence alone.
title: Common-sense utopia tacitly assumes the governance capacity it claims to bracket
